Tyler Close wrote:
> On Wednesday 02 July 2003 21:42, Paul Prescod wrote:
> 
>>Trying to decide how many resources there are behind a URL is kind of an
>>angels-on-the-head-of-a-pin question.
> 
> Unfortunately, REST only says "important" resources should have a
> URI. This leaves us with a subjective test.

Unfortunately this is unavoidable. Similarly in an OO language you would 
say that important resources should be represented as objects (as 
opposed to being embedded in strings, for example).

> I take it from your response that you believe user-specific
> resources are not "important" and that you see no value in the
> example offered by Vincent D. Murphy?

Not at all. My point is that if Roy defines a service and says that the 
URI "/mybooks" represents the current user's books and that is a single 
resource then consumers have to treat that as the defined interface. You 
can't argue "really that's two resources". It isn't. It is one resource 
that happens to serve very different representations to different users. 
But you could _separately_ make an engineering argument that it would be 
more useful if there were multiple resources. Sure, given a set of goals 
and requirements for a system that is probably the right engineering 
choice. My point was that it is not productive for two people to argue 
whether a given URL has N or M resources behind it.

My rule of thumb is that the thing has multiple resources behind it if 
you have to invent a new addressing scheme to talk about the things, and 
you start embedding those addresses in XML documents or passing them 
around as parameters to APIs etc.

> As for the original example, if the application is designed
> without user-specific resource URLs, it will not be possible to
> even link to cities created by other users. Ah well, foreign
> travel is overrated anyways.

I would presume that every city has its own URL and the only question is 
whether every user is allowed to see every city or whether they get an 
authorization complaint. That's why I think that the discussion about 
user-specific URLs is a little bit of a tangent.

> 1. REST states that important resources should have a URI.

Great.

> 2. A user-specific resource is an important resource.

Great.

> 3. HTTP Auth is used to discriminate between user-specific
> resources.

HTTP auth can be used to do two things. One is to disallow access to a 
resource. The other is to personalize a resource. Let's say I send you a 
URL for a site that we both have accounts for (Slashdot is a perfect 
example). It shows up for you with a blue background because of a 
preference you set and it shows up as green for me. This is good from a 
usability point of view: you are seeing the information as you asked for 
it and I am seeing it as I asked for it. It is the same resource.

Conversely, it could be quite confusing if the URL behaves totally 
differently for me than for you (not just different colours but totally 
different content). On the other hand, if this is part of the contract 
of the resource ("We use your user name as the seed for a random number 
generator before we generate you a random quote") then fair enough.

  Paul Prescod
